javaslang.control

Class Success<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • javaslang.control.Success<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - component type of this Success
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Try<T>, FilterMonadic<Try<?>,T>, Kind<Try<?>,T>, Value<T>

    public final class Success<T>
extends Object
implements Try<T>, Serializable
    A succeeded Try.
    Since:
    1.0.0
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • recover

        public Success<T> recover(Function<Throwable,? extends T> f)
        Description copied from interface: Try
        Returns this, if this is a Success, otherwise tries to recover the exception of the failure with f, i.e. calling Try.of(() -> f.apply(throwable)).
        Specified by:
        recover in interface Try<T>
        Parameters:
        f - A recovery function taking a Throwable
        Returns:
        a new Try

      • recoverWith

        public Success<T> recoverWith(Function<Throwable,Try<T>> f)
        Description copied from interface: Try
        Returns this, if this is a Success, otherwise tries to recover the exception of the failure with f, i.e. calling f.apply(cause.getCause()). If an error occurs recovering a Failure, then the new Failure is returned.
        Specified by:
        recoverWith in interface Try<T>
        Parameters:
        f - A recovery function taking a Throwable
        Returns:
        a new Try

      • filter

        public Try<T> filter(Predicate<? super T> predicate)
        Description copied from interface: Try

        Returns this if this is a Failure or this is a Success and the value satisfies the predicate.

        Returns a new Failure, if this is a Success and the value does not satisfy the Predicate or an exception occurs testing the predicate.

        Specified by:
        filter in interface Try<T>
        Specified by:
        filter in interface FilterMonadic<Try<?>,T>
        Parameters:
        predicate - A predicate
        Returns:
        a new Try

      • flatMapM

        public <U> Try<U> flatMapM(Function<? super T,? extends Kind<? extends Try<?>,? extends U>> mapper)
        Description copied from interface: FilterMonadic
        Flat maps the elements of this elements of a new type preserving their order, if any.

        This method effectively does call 

        this.flatMap((Function<? super T, ? extends M<? extends U>>) mapper);
        It exists, because Java's type system (the lack of higher-order kinds) does not allow us to define an interface containing the mentioned flatMap method.
        Specified by:
        flatMapM in interface Try<T>
        Specified by:
        flatMapM in interface FilterMonadic<Try<?>,T>
        Type Parameters:
        U - Component type of the flat mapped FilterMonadic
        Parameters:
        mapper - A mapper.
        Returns:
        a flat mapped FilterMonadic

      • flatten

        public Try<Object> flatten()
        Flattens this Value.

        The semantics may vary from class to class. The commonality is, that some kind of wrapped state is recursively unwrapped.

        Example: 

        (((1))).flatten() = (1)
        Specified by:
        flatten in interface Try<T>
        Specified by:
        flatten in interface FilterMonadic<Try<?>,T>
        Returns:
        A flattened version of this Value.

      • mapTry

        public <U> Try<U> mapTry(CheckedFunction1<? super T,? extends U> f)
        Description copied from interface: Try
        Runs the given checked function if this is a Success, passing the result of the current expression to it. If this expression is a Failure then it'll return a new Failure of type R with the original exception. The main use case is chaining checked functions using method references: 
         
 Try.of(() -> 0)
    .mapTry(x -> 1 / x); // division by zero
        Specified by:
        mapTry in interface Try<T>
        Type Parameters:
        U - The new component type
        Parameters:
        f - A checked function
        Returns:
        a new Try

      • andThen

        public Try<T> andThen(Try.CheckedConsumer<? super T> consumer)
        Description copied from interface: Try
        Runs the given checked consumer if this is a Success, passing the result of the current expression to it. If this expression is a Failure then it'll return a new Failure of type T with the original exception. The main use case is chaining checked functions using method references: 
         
 Try.of(() -> 100)
    .andThen(i -> System.out.println(i));
        Specified by:
        andThen in interface Try<T>
        Parameters:
        consumer - A checked consumer taking a single argument.
        Returns:
        a new Try
